text:
Divine!  Sublime!!  LOVED this soup!!!  No changes needed though perhaps a suggestion?  Use 6 cups of beef broth versus 5 and add only as much tortellini as you plan on eating at each serving.  The soup literally sopes up the broth, so if you have leftovers (which are even BETTER the next day) you have no broth as the tortellini has absorbed it!   Thanks to Mary P - my hat's off to you!!!!

text:
WOW! Delicious! Everyone LOVED this soup and went back for seconds. I served it with the foccacia bread recipe from this site, YUM! Only thing I changed was used broth instead of water and added 1 cup of spinach.  To make it more practical I just used 3 cans beef broth which is a little over 5 cups.  2 medium sized carrots equals 1 cup and 1 medium sized zucchini equals 1.5 cups.  I used petite cut diced canned tomatoes, drained - about a can and a half was perfect! DO NOT add any salt to this soup - I used low-sodium broth and it was a tad too salty for me.  Thank you for this great recipe!

text:
This is one of the best soups I have ever made!  Quick tip-to peel your tomatoes slice a criss-cross on the top of the tomato and drop it into boiling water for just a few seconds, drain them and put them immediately in an ice bath.  The skins will come right off, and then you can cut them in half and squeeze the seeds out.  This is a must make!

text:
This soup is absolutely amazing! The first time I made it I used canned tomatoes instead of fresh and sweet Italian sausage... The second time I used hot sausage and took the time to peel/seed fresh tomatoes...it was worth it! The second soup was much better! I found the canned tomatoes to overpower the broth... and the hot sausage added a great kick! I want to make it over and over... serve with crusty bread and the rest of the bottle of wine ;)

text:
I used 4 links of spicy italian sausage, used 2 cups of chicken broth for some of the beef becasue I had some in the fridge, omitted the water, used a shiraz for the wine & increased it a bit, used dry basil, used frozen squash slices for the zuchinni, added some frozen sugar snap peas (cut in half), used parmesan-filled tortellini & added additional liquids because I made some additions to the recipe. (talk about a run-on sentence...I can feel all you English teachers wincing! LOL) This made a huge pot so I pulled enough out to feed hubby & I & then added the tortellini to our portions. (I didn't want the tortellini to get sogged out if frozen in soup)...freezing the rest before the peas & squash were fully cooked. It should be good as new when thawed. Served it w/ some parmesan breadsticks, a glass of shiraz & a salad....thanks Mary P!

text:
I thought this was just ok,  but Hubs particularly liked this as it is indicative of the rich, tomato-based, boldly flavored soups he's so fond of.  I loosely followed the recipe, but used fresh herbs and my own tomato sauce from my garden rather than the fresh tomatoes and canned tomato sauce. This is the sort of good old-fashioned soup that begs to be tinkered with, using whatever you have on hand so everything gets used and nothing goes to waste. So many vegetables would work with this and a a can of cannellini or ceci (garbanzo) beans would be nice too.  This is a little more "robust" than I personally tend to like, but after one spoonful just to taste (we're actually having this tomorrow) Hubs said, "Oh ye-aah.  This is just the way I like it."

text:
Update: 6/11
I used wine (as the recipe calls for) for the first time. HUGE difference. The flavor is much more rounded. Don't pass on the vino!!
Family favorite! The only difference is I cook the tortellini seperately and once I serve it into bowls I pour the soup over the noodles. Then the noodles don"t sop up the broth or get mushy. I always cook a double batch and freeze some. Although my family fights over who gets the leftovers so sometimes it doesn't make it to the freezer. :).

text:
One of my new favorite soups!  Even though I used diced canned tomatoes and dried herbs, I thought this soup was rich tasting.  I mixed mild and hot sausage together to add a little more heat to the broth.   I used a cheap red wine, and I don't think it made any difference in flavor.  I also subbed 1 can tomato soup for the sauce because that's what I had.  I used green beans instead of zucchini to save a trip to the store. Quick to put together and good enough for guests!  Add some crusty French or Italian bread, and you've got a delicious meal for a cold nights' dinner.  Thanks, Mary!

text:
This was a good soup but it's not on my "favorites" list. I made this with hot italian sausage since that's what hubby likes. Mine turned out a little on the salty side, but I ran out of beef broth and had to add a little chicken stock...so that may have been why.  I didn't have the fresh tomatoes so I used canned (which I like) and used a 6 oz can of tomato paste since I was out of tomato sauce. My husband enjoyed this and asked me to hold on to the left-overs for him.  I like all of the ingredients that went into this soup, so I'm not sure why I didn't enjoy it more.  I've been eyeing this recipe for a long time..so I'm glad I gave it a shot.  Thanks Mary.

text:
Wonderful soup and a great way to get your veggies. I use Hot Italian sausage, 3 cans of beef broth, skip the wine and add 1 cup water. Also saute the onions and garlic in olive oil instead of the sausage grease. I don't use fresh basil or parsley, just the dehydrated flakes from the seasoning aisle. Have made with up to 19oz of cheese tortellini or half that if I want to save some. The tortellini instructions are sketchy, just cook them till they float. This soup is great! Served w/some Tuscan bread & dipping sauce (oil and herbs). It's also very filling. Thanks for a great recipe!

If I could give this 10 stars I would!  This soup is so good!  I am not usually a sausage fan, but I really enjoyed it in the soup.  I served it for a causal dinner party with rosemary bread and some salad and it got rave reviews.  I can't wait to make this again. I also put some fresh basil on top to serve as I felt it lost flavor as it cooked in the soup.

text:
I'm just cooking this now and it smells really amazing.  The only other thing I added is a bit of fennel seed that I crushed up.  I've been putting that in a lot of Italian sauces lately.  It's probably already in the sausage but it gives it a nice aroma.  I wish I had put it in while sauteeing the sausage but I added it to the broth with everything else.  Update:  EVERYONE I've ever fed this to has LOVED it, including a good friend who is a professionally trained chef and wanted the recipe!

Display Name:
MrHappy1353

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/55359.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, very tasty!  I made this pretty much by the original recipe, but with the following changes;  Tomatoes aren't good this time of year so I used 2 cans of organic diced tomatoes.  The shopper in our family brought back frozen meat tortellini instead of fresh, so we used those and they turned out great.  The only other thing I did was after removing the casings from the sweet Italian sausage I cut them into bite size pieces and browned them in a saute pan.  I then took them out piece by piece and put them into a paper towel lined bowl to absorb the excess fat.  This worked really well and I didn't need to skim any fat off the soup because there wasn't any!  I served this with sourdough rolls and the crowd went wild!  Great recipe, and I thank the original poster.

text:
great! i made some changes based on what i had, but i think it would be delicious exactly as written as well. i omitted the water and used extra broth and wine instead for more flavor, and i used two cans of tomato sauce instead of one and the four tomatoes. i also left out the carrots and zucchini (i didn't have any), added about 2 tbsp of heavy cream for a slightly more substantial broth, and added about 1/2 c parmesan cheese while it was cooking. for a more substantial soup, double the tortellini but only add an extra 1/2 of the amount of everything else in the recipe.

text:
This soup was amazing, as other reviewers suggested I cooked the tortellini separate. I was using a brand of tortellini I had never tried before (because I usually buy the frozen kind and the recipe said not to) which I did not really care for. When I had some leftovers the next day I threw in some white rice I had on hand instead of the funky tasting tortellini and it was fantastic! I will definitely make again, using rice because it is much cheaper and better than I can imagine tortellini (even some that I really liked) tasting -- I will also be dubbing this "Italian Gumbo".

Wow is one word to sum up  the delicious-ness of this soup! Like other reviewers next time I will add at LEAST one more cup of broth, even 2 more 2 cups with another 1/4 cup of wine (i really love to cook with the wine literally called "red") the wine really brings out a bolder flavor. Everything else was the same.  But raves ALL around, my baby girl couldn't stop saying mmmmmm ! (neither could anyone else)

text:
Great Flavor!  I read many reviews before I attempted to make this for the first time.  I figured from the reviews that I couldn't go wrong.  I followed the recipe very closely with just a couple changes.  First, I used half fresh tomatos, and half diced from a can.  I also used 3 cups of beef broth and 2 of chicken broth to make it less beefy.  I couldn't find sweet sausage, so I used half mild and half hot sausage (being married to a mexican, a little kick always helps:).  The last thing I did different is use 3 cheese tortellini, because we love cheese!  This really is a tasty soup, Like button:)

text:
This was the first soup I've made in a long time and it was great.  Though the original recipe doesn't call for it, I saw a container of baby portobello slices while shopping and thought I'd add it, I highly recommend it if you like mushrooms!  I put them in early when I was browning the sausage (mild italian, couldn't find sweet) then set both aside to add back later.  I used Rolling Stones 40 Licks Merlot from Wines that rock (I really like their wines and they add nice flavors when cooking).  I wasn't able to find tortellini but the bowtie I used worked fine.  I definitely liked this soup and everyone else did to, even a family friend who's 4 which was unexpected.  I'd like to make this again and add cannellini beans, but it's perfect as it is.

text:
This soup is so colorful and so good. I used reduced sodium beef broth and no-salt canned tomatoes; I would recommend using as many reduced sodium ingredients as possible in this recipe as it definitely leans to the salty side.  My zucchini was too old, so I used 1/2 cup of frozen spinach in its place which worked well.  Since others remarked that the tortellini absorbed a lot of the soup liquid, I just kept them separate and added them into the bowl as I served the soup.  Next time, I would add more basil & oregano.

Made this the night before a carry-in at work. Excellent! I used 2 cans of petite diced tomatoes. I was worried about the salt content and quantity of broth, based on other reviews.  I used one 32 oz carton of Kitchen Basic NO SALT beef broth and 8 oz of another carton regular salted beef broth. I ended up adding the remaining 24oz, because it really did absorb quite a bit of liquid overnight. Between the two cartons, did not feel it was too salty at all. Yummy.

text:
Another 5 star rating here!  I've always made a more traditional minestrone soup but I think I like this even better!  I questioned using beef broth instead of chicken but went with it since I always like to try (and review) recipes as written.  I'm glad I did - it made the soup rich and hearty.  I did have to make a couple minor changes simply because I was making this from what I had on hand... I didn't have tomato sauce so I used a big tablespoonful of tomato paste (had one open I needed to use); I also didn't have zucchini so I used some peeled diced delicata squash that I had; I also threw in some chopped fresh kale and spinach to add some greens.  Otherwise as-written.  Fantastic and the family loved it.  Will definitely make again (and again and again!).  Thanks!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/741609.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantasic hearty soup!! It sort of reminded me of a minestrone soup. I doubled the recipe to make sure I had enough for a family get-together. Made a few changes...I used fresh made hot italian sausage, in lieu of all beef broth I used 1/3 beef broth, 1/3 my homemade saltfree chicken stock, and 1/3 my homemade saltfree tomato juice (obviously I watch the salt intake!), omitted the zuchinni, added 1 c. pipette pasta, added 1 can pinto beans & 1 can of red beans (rinsed both before adding). Don't be afraid to add more water, broth, or tomato juice because the pasta definitely uses it up. I think the next time I make this I will add some chopped swiss chard or some of those flat italian green beans cut in 1" pieces. I served it with a crusty italian bread. This soup was definitely a hit! Easy to make and easy to tweek!

text:
Yum! I skipped the zucchini because I didn't have any on hand and I subbed cilantro for parsley because I am madly in love with cilantro (and therefore, so is my garden). I also used a whole diced onion, which was closer to 2 cups. (Big thank you to the reviewer Nikki who translated cups into quantities of veggies!) Everybody raved except my 9-year-old, so I think when I make this again it'll be on a grown-ups night, and I'll use hot Italian sausage and some maybe some black or red pepper. I accidentally put in one can of beef broth plus a carton of low-sodium chicken broth. I know it doesn't make a huge difference, but I was irritated with myself (I literally just grabbed the wrong carton from the pantry!), so I "noticed." Again, everybody raved, and I see other reviewers used chicken broth on purpose (not just because they were on the phone with their mother and not paying attention...), but I will definitely use beef next time because I think that little extra richness and saltiness would have made it EVEN better! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This soup is 10 STARS for flavor for sure! I used homemade beef stock with 1/2 qt. home canned tomatoes with the juice in place of the 4 lg. tomatoes (what I had on hand) and I did not add water or red wine. I added substancially more carrots, a 16 oz. bag of tortellini and 1 1/2 lb. sausage. I had frozen basil in the freezer in ice cube trays from my garden so I threw in one large cube of basil instead of 1/2 Tbps. fresh. This soup was outstanding! And both my sons and my husband said that it was their favorite soup ever! I will be making this often. It was also VERY EASY to through together.

text:
Soup was tasty, opted to leave out zucchini and didn't have a dry red wine. Used four cloves of garlic, 16oz of tortellini, 1.5lbs of sausage. Used mild and spicy sausage, which made the soup spicy, perfect on a cold day--sweaty on a warm day. Next time, I'll try with sweet sausage. Instead of using fresh tomatoes, used a large 28oz can of crushed tomatoes, just didn't have time to prep the fresh ones. Though I'd love to try it some day. Added equal part beef broth instead of the wine since I didn't have it. Next time I'll also add more stock, maybe one or two more cups, the tortellini absorbs a good amount. Served with very delicious Garlic Bread.

country:

text:
I made this soup as is the first time and it was fantastic!  However I prefer even a heartier soup so the second time I made it I made it a little differently based on that and what I had on hand.  I used turkey kielbasa in place of sausage. I chopped 4 carrots, 3 stalks of celery and two onions.  I didnt have any zucchini so kept that out.  I used 1 can of petite diced tomatoes instead of fresh.  Used a splash more wine (cabernet sauvignon) than called for and then I also added some thyme, cayenne pepper and 2 bay leaves to the pot.  OMG!!! the depth of flavors and the richness of the broth!  Oh and I also used a 16oz package of frozen tortellini that I thawed and added!  Will be making this again and again!

I made this recently for my mother and grandmother(who are excellent cooks--talk about pressure!).  It really was excellent.  I was so proud(and relieved!).  I didn't even use fresh basil or parsley or garlic!  I used dried for the basil and parsley, and jarred minced garlic, because that is what I had on hand.  I also simply used canned tomatoes. (Sorry...I have three small kids...I have to cut corners where I can!) It may taste better following the recipe exactly; but, we didn't miss a thing!  It was delicious!  Oh....I also used ground Italian sausage(Johnsonville, I think), instead of links.  That way I didn't have to touch the meat to remove casings!  I don't think you can wrong.  I'm gonna make it tonight!

text:
This soup was a great way to use up things I had in the kitchen. I made a few changes based on what I had on hand- I omitted the zucchini and added chopped green peppers and celery. I did not have fresh herbs so I used Italian Seasoning. I used fresh tortellini that had been frozen. Also, I browned the sausage in a pan and cooked the onions, garlic and peppers for a few minutes. Then I put everything in the slow cooker and cooked it on high for about 3 hours. Will make again!

text:
This was a fantastic recipe. Due to lack of availability here, I ended up using dry tortellini with spinach and there was no loss overall - per an earleir suggestion, spinach was a nice addition. While I wouldnt not typically think to use a sweet italian sausage, it was a great compliment to the flavors - I recommend NOT cutting corners here, even if you like spice like I do. My only concern was that it definitely got hearty and thick with the tortellini added, If you like more broth, it might be advisable to add an extra 2 cups of broth as well as the water.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed advice of others and used low sodium broth,and half spicy/half regular sausage. Also, my kids don't like zucchini, so I used frozen itallian green beans instead, and hand-crushed canned whole tomatoes easily replaced fresh. I also used more basil than called for while simmering soup and reserved a little extra to snip onto soup in bowls to refresh the flavor. Someone commented about it not freezing well. The key to freezing any soup with tortellini is to make extra soup and reserve soup broth with all the veggies, etc.  freeze as is without the tortellini added, and when you're ready to enjoy the soup again, simply thaw and bring to boil adding tortellini for the last 10 mins of prep.

Delicious.  It was okay the first night, but the second night...wow.  Awesome.  It definitely helps to let the flavors marry overnight in the fridge.

The only substitutions I made were out of necessity.  I used muir glen fire-roasted tomatoes instead of fresh.  I also used dry basil instead of fresh basil. I'm pretty sure if I had used fresh the recipe would have been even more awesome, but it still tasted good with the dry herbs.

Display Name:
CAKES CORNER by WILILYN
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/790896.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
PERFECTO!
I cooked and diced Italian Sausage first, then added 1 cup chopped onion, 5 cloves pressed garlic (WE LOVE GARLIC), sauteed in the pan altogether. Then I added 5 cups beef broth, 1/2 cup water 1/2 cup red wine, 4 large tomatoes - peeled and chopped, DID NOT seed tomatoes, 1 Italian canned diced tomatoes, 1 cup shredded carrots with Cheese Grater, 1 teaspoon dried basil, 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano, pinch of pepper flakes, 1 (8 ounce) can tomato sauce, OMITTED. After simmering for 30 minutes, I added 1 1/2 cups cubed zucchini, and served with cooked tortellini pasta, sprinkled chopped fresh parsley and Parmesan Cheese.
Thank you!

city:

country:

text:
its an excellent recipe. I adjusted to my own preference.  and you know what people that get angry that we adjust its a recipe.  I did use more garlic I used 3 cloves when i sauted my onions and garlic in olive oil... I used the jimmy dean hot breakfast sausage roll because target didnt have the italian sausage and it turned out great.  I added 3 bay leaves for the first 30 minutes italian seasoning...wasnt going to pay 3 dollars for fresh basil so i used dried basil and the italian seasoning... I also added cut up mushrooms with the zucchini at the end i used 1 fresh tomato and  1 can tomatoes for the first 30 minutes with a hint of poultry seasoning.  overall i think the recipe is great! will make again.  also seperated my tortellini from my soup so it wouldnt soak up all the juices the next day.  Love leftovers.  my spouse ate 2 bowls of it and i did too. next time i  might add more vegies...  but seasoning is always a must.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/43355.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic!  This was one of the best soups I have made.  I used turkey sausage to cut down on the fat, beef broth in place of water, and a can of petite diced tomatoes (drained) and two medium tomatoes, as it is all I had on hand.  I also used dried herbs instead of fresh and the flavor was still great. I knew we would have leftovers, as it's just the two of us, so I put the soup we would eat that night into a smaller pot and then added the tortellini and a handful of spinach and simmered for about 10 minutes so the pasta wouldn't soak up all the broth sitting in the fridge.  Now when we reheat it, we can do the same and still have a good amount of broth.

text:
Wonderfully delicious soup. My husband is not a fan of soups with veggies in them but he adored this soup. It was a hearty, filling soup that produced enough leftovers for lunches for the remainder of the week. I made the recipe pretty much as is except I only had 2 cans of beef broth so I used one full can of water. I also did not have any red wine so I omitted that. I used canned tomatoes and dried basil. I made homemade croutons with french baguette and topped the soup with those and an Italian blend cheese. Thank you for sharing this amazing recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very easy and super yummy!  I had to make a couple of edits so that the kids would eat it:  I omitted the zucchini and whole tomatoes since they are not favorites of the 10 and under crowd.  I used a 14 oz can of tomato sauce instead of the 8 oz to accommodate for the missing tomatoes.  I also added dark red kidney beans since I took out the zucchini and instead of tortellini (I didn't have any on hand) I used cavatappi (corkscrew).  For a slightly healthier spin, I used turkey Italian sausage.  Will definitely make again--perfect for a cold winter day!  Thank you!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe and very flexible.  If you stick with the basic ingredients, you'll have a great soup.  Don't have any wine - add more broth.  Don't like zucchini - omit or add something else.  Lots of green beans on hand - throw 'em in.   Personally, I used sweet sausage and canned tomatoes.  My husband isn't fond of zucchini, so I added it whole, removed it when cooked through, pureed it in the food processor and added it back to the broth.   I served a spinach salad and garlic bread and both complimented the soup especially well.  Dinner was delish!

STARDUST_331

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/40384.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sausage soup with funky pasta, that's what my hubby calls it.  This recipe is sooo good.  Even my 19 m month old ATE. IT. UP. - carrots, tomatoes, zucchini, onions and all, even drinking up the soup by taking the bowl to her mouth or with a straw. I actually used a pound of sweet and a pound of hot sausage (I meant to take out a pound and freeze it for later), but it turned out fine.  I used 2 cans of stewed tomatoes instead of chopped tomatoes and 1 can of fire-roasted tomatoes, forgot to add the sauce and a pound of tortellini.  I always cook the tortellini on its own and mix it in after - I found the starch adds too much gunk to the soup. I always forget the tomato sauce but think that it would add a nice bit of body to the soup.  I like to use something heavy like cabernet sauvignon (buy those 4 packs of little bottles if you don't drink red wines - perfect for cooking). Serve with some shredded parmesean cheese and a hunk of ciabatta bread - This soup is delicious!!

I can't wait until it's fully finished. I know that this is going to become a family favorite!! As soon as I'm done typing this out I'm going to email the recipe to my sister. I did make a few substitutions though...mild Italian sausage instead of sweet (which I'm going to hunt down for next time) and de-alcoholized wine instead of the regular kind. THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU  Mary P for this recipe!!!

text:
Yummy!  This was delicious, fast and super easy to make!  I was in a hurry to make dinner, so I browned the sausage, onion and used garlic powder all together.  Then I just added all the ingredients in the pan. Added the broth, tomato sauce and carrots, no wine or diced tomatoes.  I didn't used zucchini, I used frozen caulliflower and spinach instead.  Used dry basil and fresh cilantro.  Threw in premade tortelli (the ones in the packages) in the soup and let it all boil for about 30 minutes.  Didn't need any cheese or toppings, it was great as it.  Thank you!

userID:

Display Name:
Michelle Miller Motley

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1378667.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum!!  I did make some changes and was thrilled with the results.  My version: 2 links of hot italian turkey sausage (casings removed, crumbled), 1/2 package of diced pepperoni, 1 med onion, 3 cloves of garlic, 6 cups chicken broth, omitted the water, 1/2 cup red wine, 1 can (14.5 oz) diced tomatoes (Italian flavored with basil, garlic, oregeno), carrots (baby carrots cut in half), 1/2 tbl freeze dried basil (great taste, much better than normal dried basil), 1/2 tsp Italian seasoning, 8 oz tomato sauce, 2 cups zucchini, 10 oz Rosetto cheese tortellini (frozen), generous dash of dried parsley, generous dash of red pepper flakes.  I added the carrots with the zucchini(last 30 min., so carrots would not get overcooked).  Last 10 min I turned the heat to low and added the tortellini.

Next time I think I will add 1 cup of wine, the 1/2 cup was very subtle.

text:
This is a great soup.  If you love tortellini and sausage that is.  Its warm and is a meal in and of itself with some crusty bread.  Mine came out a little salty, and I think it was the beef broth I used. Next time I will use a low sodium brand.  I think this would be good with a little more tomatoe flavor as well.  The tortellini suck up a lot of the broth when its left to sit, so I had to add water the next day when I was having the left overs.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to add tomato paste (about 8 ozs) as some others said and also some Better than Bouillon beef au jus starter (which I think is better than their plain beef flavor) to make this soup taste richer and more flavorful. I also added a package of fresh baby spinach. If I make it again I'll replace some of the beef broth with a can of beef consommé for richer flavor. I am boiling the tortellini separate and will add it to the soup to avoid it sucking up all the liquid. I used all fresh ingredients at the end of the summer (fresh organic heirloom tomatoes, fresh basil & parsley from my own herb garden, fresh organic zucchini and so forth). I was hoping it would have a better flavor all on its own per the reviews but it certainly needed some sprucing up --  hence the three star rating. Served with crusty, cheesy garlic bread.

city:

country:
None
text:
I varied the recipe slightly based on what I had on hand.  Because fresh tomatoes are generally horrible this time of year, I substituted a 14.5 oz. can of diced tomatoes; substituted half a diced fennel bulb for one of the zucchini; used a rich chicken stock instead of the beef broth; dried tortellini for fresh; and substituted dried Italian seasoning for the basil and oregano.  Finally, I sauteed the sausage starting in a cold dry pan simultaneously with the onions and garlic (a Chef John trick, BTW)and added the wine first, allowing it to evaporate before adding the broth.  All in all, excellent!

To add nutrition, we add a couple of cans of beans--great northern and kidney.  We also add fresh spinach right before we eat it.  My husband loves the pasta, but I find it gets soggy...so only add what you are going to eat right away. I make it in the crock pot and it makes the entire house smell amazing!  I make enough for us to eat it for lunch all week and it keeps wonderfully---if you don't add the pasta.

text:
The best soup I've ever made. I think the success of the soup depends on the sausage you use. If you use a spicy sausage, it will be extremely spicy after it simmers for 70 minutes. If you use a bland sausage, the result will be bland. If you're not familiar with the sausage you are using, microwave a small portion and taste it so you can make adjustments. Excellent recipe. Thank you Mary!

text:
FABULOUS! Ok I'm the type of cook that doesn't really measure and I have a hard time following the recipe EXACTLY, its just one of those things, thats why I usually don't rate anything.  Well I made meatballs from 93% ground beef mixed with sweet italian sausage and browned them. Then I  sauteed the garlic, onion, carrots and some celery together, then added the sliced yellow and green zucchini and added italian seasoning and little sea salt, sprinkled a little corn starch on everything (so it would be a bit thinker) and mixed in 2 cans diced tomatoes. By accident  I used canned tomatoes with diced with green chilis but I LIKE the little spice it gave.  XTRA wine and a can of tomato sauce. YUMMY!!!!!! PLEASE Don't get me wrong... I am not saying this is better than the original recipe, I just like what happened in my kitchen as I started to cook. and wanted to share. ITS A KEEPER!!!!!!

userID:
1718636
Display Name:
Cheryl
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice. My only note is that I NEVER, ever, ever cook rice, noodles or pasta in any soup I make. I cook them separately, then after I drain them, I add a little of the broth to the rice, noodles or pasta in their pan (to keep them from sticking) and then I serve them separately. I do the same with spaghetti sauce. The starches change the broths and make them impossible to store leftovers because they will continue to absorb the liquid. Also, it gives the diners more of choice. I actually learned this lesson with stew: I made a pot for dinner and a 2nd for the freezer. When I went to defrost it all I had left was meat - it had absorbed ALL the broth!

text:
YUMMIE! Loved this soup as did my family. When I went to buy the ingredients the tomatoes didn't look very good so I did buy canned and they worked fine.  Would have preferred to use fresh.  Like Crystal I did add extra broth as well, just as needed.  The only negative I find in making this wonderful soup is the skimming. It's just tedious. I was considering browning my sausage gently then removing it and letting it boil in a separate pot so that I don't need to skim......any suggestions are welcomed.  I added a photo, I am now convinced I need white dishes!!  BTW, I did garnish with parmesan and basil.

text:
This soup was delicious!  I was taking a chance by making it because my husband doesn't normally like Italian sausage, and I have a picky toddler.  But all of us love it!  I made a few substitutions because I was missing the exact ingredients: I used 1 28oz can of diced tomatoes with the juice and a can of Campbell's tomato soup, instead of the fresh tomatoes and tomato sauce; I didn't have any carrots or zucchini but I put in green pepper; I didn't have any wine.
It was delicious the way I made it. I'm sure it would be good the original way too, but I can't say for sure which is why I only gave it 4 stars.  My version is a 5 star for me!

Display Name:
caseyboggs7

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/672916.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i used 1 lb jiimmy dean zesty hot italian sausage, 1 cup chopped white onion, FOUR cloves minced garlic, 6 beef bouillon cubes dissolved in 6 cups boiling water (will use 7 next time) 1 cup water, 3/4 c Merlot wine, 1.5 BIG cans diced italian seasoned tomatoes (perfect amt and you could not taste any diff between those and fresh) 1 1/4 cup of the pre sliced carrots you buy in a bag with the crinkle indentations in them, A FULL TBL fresh chopped basil, 1/2 teaspoon oregano, a few pinches of my mixed italian herb spice, 1 1/2 cups sliced "half moon" zucchini, (perfect amt) 8 oz fresh 3 cheese tortellini, and 3 TBL fresh parsley. Besides my few minor adjustments I followed the recipe EXACTLY and it literally could be served at Olive Garden. Fantastic, a lot like OG's Minestrone but with pasta and spicy sausage. Cant wait to make again. PS doooont put any salt in this soup if you use the bouillon cubes (I used lite sodium and without that it would have been too salty) and esp if you use the canned tomatoes :]

userID:

Display Name:
Karen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this soup and have been making it for about 20 years now.  Every where I've taken it and everyone who's tasted it has raved about it.  I make a few minor changes that you might like too.  I use corn instead of carrots; chicken broth instead of beef - the flavor of the beef broth is too strong for me.  I don't like wine in cooking (or at all) so I sub extra chicken broth for the wine) and I don't peel the tomatoes, just seed and dice.  I serve it with a little grated cheddar cheese over the top and garlic bread on the side.   Garlic bread - roast a head of garlic with a tablespoon of olive oil, sprinkle a little seasoning, bake for 45 min.  Squeeze into 1 stick of butter (Smart Balance - gotta cut back somewhere!  LOL!) and add a little fresh finely chopped garlic and spread on french bread, then sprinkle with a tiny bit of garlic powder and a teeny tiny bit of salt and maybe a little paprika and bake @ 350 until golden and crusty.

So yummy and hearty!  I would make a few very minor modifications next time, but otherwise followed it to the T.  1) Use 2 cans (4 cups) beef broth, as I ended up w/ too much broth 2) Increased amount of veggies (used 3-4 carrots, 2 zucchini) and doubled the garlic 3) As suggested by many reviewers, I cooked only as much tortellini as I would eat in that sitting, so it wouldn't soak up all the broth

HEAVENLY!!!!   Words just can't quite express how yummy it was!  Changes:  I used sweet TURKEY sausage instead of Pork...cuts down the fat, more flavor.  I tripled the basil and added more veggies.  Skipped the water/wine and just added more broth.  When reading the recipe and thought for sure it would be bland because it didn't call for salt or pepper. It seriously does not need it!  The sausage and broth give enough flavor/salt on their own.  Fantastic soup!!

text:
I absolutely love this soup.  It's the perfect companion to a blustery fall day!  I used Red, yellow, and green onions, and much like other reviewers, added no salt and less stock so it's not too salty.  I also used hot Italian sausage.  I dislike zucchini, so it was omitted from the recipe, and I added celery instead.  I've tried it with fresh and canned tomatoes, and there is little to no difference in the taste, but the canned tomatoes save so much time!  I highly recommend this soup>>> :)

text:
EXCEPTIONAL soup! Wonderful, wonderful recipe! Thanks, Mary, for sharing this full flavored soup. It is simple and easy to make, which, combined with the results deserves 5 stars. Served it for dinner along with Loaded Baked Potato Soup, Fabulous Fargozas (a herb, cheese and garlic muffin, which I have submitted the recipe but don't know when it will be posted on the site) and hot french bread for dipping. Every one ohed and ahhed over the meal. Both soups were the stars and no one could say which they loved more. I did make one small alteration, I used fresh spinach leaves in place of the zucchini. Oh, and I had accidentally started to add meat tortellini. When I realized this mistake I added cheese tortellini, so there was about 1/2 and 1/2. Either flavor is great and both together is even better. This soup is very versatile, but the base ingredients are a must, as they are what provide the depth of flavor to this soup.

userID:
2929684
Display Name:
Julie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:

20
favoritesCount:
248
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is out of this world! I used my crock pot. The night before I sauteed onion and garlic; cooked a pound of hot italian sausage; diced 3 medium carrots; used the last of my garden tomatoes plus one can of diced tomatoes; and 2 medium zucchinis. I put the onions/garlic, carrots, tomatoes and half of the sausage in a bowl. I put the zucchini in a zip top bag and the other half of the cooked sausage in its own bag and put everything in the fridge til morning. I set out the needed spices, red wine and beef stock on the counter, so early the next morning I threw the meat/veggies I had in the bowl in the crock pot (minus the zucchini at this point). I used all beef stock, no water. I upped the spices called for to my liking, and added about 3 Tbs of tomato paste because I needed to use it up. Cooked on low. After about 4 hrs, I put in the zucchini. I let it go another 3 hrs or so, tossed in the fresh pasta (I used mini cheese ravioli). Half hr later, the soup was done. Using half the amount of hot sausage was perfect. It was plenty spicy. You can always add more of the sausage if it's not spicy enough but you can't take it out if it ends up too spicy. Positively magnificent. Make this a regular in your rotation! It was served with whole grain garlic bread and green salad.

As I'm writing this, I have a pot of this soup simmering on the stove. My second one in 2 days. My family just loved this Sausage Soup and as soon as they finished the 1st pot I made they requested,no wait, begged me to make a 2nd. text:
Lately when I try a 4 1/2-5 star recipe I've been incredibly disappointed.  Sometimes I think a few people will give it a 5 star rating just to get the ball rolling and others follow suit.  It simply makes no sense and I'm completely baffled as to why some of these recipes get 5 star ratings.  THIS is NOT one of those recipes.  This recipe DESERVES a 5 STAR rating.  It's incredibly easy and delicious.  I followed the recipe exactly with the exception of using canned tomatoes, and omitting the zucchini.  I did slice the carrots thinly as recommended and I’ve found that I prefer carrots sliced thinly in soup rather than thickly sliced.  It adds a nice texture to the soup.  You could pretty much add any vegetables you wanted to this soup.  Just play with it and add what you like.  Great recipe!

Soooooo good! I have made similar dishes several times before. I had sweet turkey sausage on hand and added crushed red pepper flakes since I like spicy. I used fresh three cheese tortellini and four fresh tomatoes- skinned and deseeded them as other veiwers suggested. I didn't have a zucchini on hand so I used spinach instead. It wasn't too salty for us, maybe because of the low soduim broth and fresh tomatoes. Served with a salad and toasted garlic bread (from this site). So full and satisfied!

text:
I love this soup SOOOO much.  Don't even read the recipe anymore I've made it so often.  I actually make it first thing in the morning (brown sausage, then veggies on the stove), dump everything (except tortellini) in the slow cooker on low.  Simmers all day. When we're ready to eat I cook the tortellini separately and then throw it in with some fresh basil leaves and/or spinach.  Yummy yummy.  I've only ever used canned tomatoes -- easier. Probably takes 15-20 minutes of effort.  Crusty bread and a salad and voila!!  Whole house smells incredible.  Sometimes I add extra fennel to up that italian sausage taste.

country:
None
text:
I'd give this 10 stars, if I could!  We LOVED this!  The only deviations from the recipe were 1) no need to drain the sausage and set aside b/c there was not enough grease to worry about, so I just tossed the onions and (extra) garlic in toward the end of browning the sausage 2) deglazed the pan with the beef broth and proceeded, which cut the cook time down by almost half and 3) didn't have zucchini or tortellini, so left the zucchini out and subbed frozen 4-cheese ravioli from Costco.  Let the ravs simmer for 5 minutes and served with freshly grated parm.  I also sliced up sourdough french bread, buttered and sprinkled with Brady Street Cheese Sprinkle from Penzey's... and stuck under the broiler.  It was SOOOOOO good... will make this one often!  Thanks, Mary!

userID:
1978964
Display Name:
IowaCookingLover

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I work a lot of hours but wanted to try this.  I changed a few things to make it faster and easier for a busy schedule.  First I used specialty italian sausage. I live in an italian neighborhood and homemade sausage is available. I also used 1 package of frozen italian vegetables which has everything in it.  I browned the meat, set aside, sauted onions, fresh mushrooms and green pepper until tender.  Then added 2 cans chicken broth.  From there 2 cans diced tomatoes which are seasoned with roasted garlic and onion, the frozen veggies, can of northern beans.  I used bulk italian seasoning, about 2T and garlic minced about 1T. I then added the meat and let it simmer.  After about 1/2 hour I brought to full boil and added frozen cheese tortellini; boiled 5 min.  Turned off the burner, covered it and let it sit while I prepared the crusty italian bread....DELICIOUS!!  You can pick and choose how to make this with the basic recipe here.  I will definately make again and again.

text:
This was so easy ans simple.  I did not have very much fat from my sausage so I added the onions and garlic while i cooked it.  I also did not do any thing as far as simming the fat and so on.  I am more of an eyeball cook so i added more Tortellini and my hubby loved that he had some for every bite.  I made a nice salad on the side and garlic bread.  (secret for a better garlic bread! spread with butter and then add some garlic powder then add some mayo on top and top with fresh Parmesan, Romano, and Asiago cheese and toast in the oven!) Give the bread a huge flavor you will  love!  Thanks for this recipe will use again and won't change a thing .

We really, really liked this recipe and my husband is NOT a soup person.  It's very hearty so it's all I served for dinner with some bread and it was great!  I used canned, crushed tomatoes instead of fresh (1 lg can) and extra zucchini and no carrots. The red wine really added something to the soup.  Yum.  I will definitely make this again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this tonight and it's delicious. I changed it up a bit as follows:
1. Only had white wine so splashed some of that in
2. Used 2 boxes of Beef Broth (didn't have any use for a partial box of left over broth
3. No fresh basil - used dried
4. Added about half cup of chopped celery because I like it!
5. Didn't add water
6. Tossed in a large handful of baby spinach because I had it in the fridge

Cooked the tortellini separately and added to the bowl of soup so the leftovers won't get soggy.
Topped with fresh shredded Parmessan
Served with a big loaf of hot crusty Italian 7 grain bread (we don't slice it , we just rip it) and lots of soft sweet butter.
SO good!
This one is a keeper!

userID:
16680062
Display Name:
MFDavies

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3604704.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very very good soup!  I followed the directions and incorporated a few things suggested by other reviewers.  Instead of 4 tomatoes, I used a 28 oz can of petite cut tomatoes, drained.  I used the prescribed 8 oz can of tomato sauce, and added 3 oz of tomato paste (it was leftover).  Instead of water, I used beef broth, bringing the beef broth to 5 1/2 cups.  Note:  I bought a 32 oz package of unsalted beef stock which gave me 4 cups.  Since I needed more, I used part of a can of beef broth.  I'm not sure if there's a difference between stock and broth?  Overall the taste was very good, though a little strong.  The vegetables cooked very nicely and had a nice texture after cooking for the prescribed time.  Next time, I will not substitute the water, and will use all low sodium broth and tomatoes.  I also cooked the tortellini separately.  When I served the soup, I put the tortellini at the bottom of the bowls, covered them with the hot soup, and sprinkled parmesan cheese over the top.  Delicious!!

userID:
12008276
Display Name:
gllybll
isPro:

followersCount:

7

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious that I am keeping it in my own recipe book.  I have made it twice.  The first time I followed the recipe exactly, and then made it again this past week and doctored it.  Both are delicious, but I prefer the changes I have made to it, which are the following:

- I prefer to use mild sausage or hot sausage
- 1 large yellow onion, chopped
- 8 cloves garlic, pressed
- 5 cups beef broth
- 2 cups chicken broth
(I changed the amount of additional liquid because in the original recipe with all the additional goodies in the pot, there wasn't enough liquid to balance out the soup. I also use chicken broth to stabilize the "beef" flavor, so it's not overpowering the dish)
- 1/2 cup red wine 
- 1 (14.5 oz) can of diced tomatoes
- 1-2 whole carrots, chopped 
- 1-(8 oz) can tomato sauce 
- 1 whole sliced zucchini 
- Italian seasoning to taste
- 1 Tblsp of brown sugar (I added this in to counter the acidic flavor of the wine, tomatoes, and the tomato sauce.  You can adjust it to your liking)
- 1 chicken bouillon cube
- 6 oz, Ronzoni Garden Delight Trio Italiano pasta blend (It's roughly about half the box)

I sauté my onions and garlic first, and then add the sausage to brown.  I don't drain the sausage before I add all the rest of the ingredients, I just skim the fat during cooking time.  The chicken bouillon, brown sugar, and Italian seasoning are all added during the second step of the recipe.

Thanks, Mary P., for providing such a yummy treat!

text:
I made this in my crock pot with a few modifications.  I cheated on the sausage by using the kind used for pizza topping.  I buy it from the warehouse store deli/canteen.  It works well for homemade pizza and calzones so I usually keep some in the freezer and because the nuggets are flash frozen I can take out only what I need.  As for the rest I followed the list pretty closely and tossed the pasta in about 20 minutes before serving.  I made it for the guys at work and the loved it.  They're always asking when I'm going to make my "pizza soup" again. A little fresh parmesan cheese and a crusty Italian loaf and it's absolute heaven!

text:
The perfect soup for a wintry day!  I made a "quick" version of this for lunch today and it came out wonderfully, so delicious!  I just browned the sausage until almost done and added the onion and garlic to it and finished, spooned the grease from the bottom of the pot, added all of the other ingredients (I used a 14 oz can fire roasted tomatoes & increased broth to 6 cups), and simmered for just 15 minutes or so.  Added the tortellini (fresh) and in another 5 minutes, done! This is a keeper.  Thank you for sharing your recipe with AR.

text:
This was a great recipe!  

I used 6 small-medium links of mild Italian turkey sausage (next time I will use spicy Italian sausage).  I used all dried seasonings and canned diced tomatoes.  I used 3 cans of beef broth (6 cups) low sodium and thought this was the perfect amount of salt (might be too salty for some- that's how I prefer it).  I didn't add water or wine and could not tell the difference.  I also omitted the zucchini and added spinach towards the end.  Great way to get veggies in and stay full!

text:
This is awesome, very flavorful.  I used 20 oz Italian sausage, only because that's how it was packed.  I also make the soup (without pasta) the day before I want to serve it.  It really improves with a day's rest.  Then I add the pasta right before I serve.  The pasta will sop up all the broth if left in for a long time.  I also tried it once with just plain penne pasta, not tortellini.  Very good, but WAY better with tortellini!

userID:
898974
Display Name:
SolarMom
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/484677.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! Yum! Yum! Great recipe. I am making more broth so that I can easily complete the soup for future dinners. I have a lot of extra red wine to use up and don't drink it! (Migraines unfortunately!) I had a soup night party and served this along with two others, it was a huge hit! A couple of things I will adjust next time, I won't cook the tortellini in the soup but will likely do it in water and beef broth so it still has the flavor it would have cooked in the soup. I will keep the two separate and put them together for each bowl. When the tortellini sits in the soup it starts to swell and soften, absorbing too much broth over time, it was also hard to divvy out the sausage with the big tortellini getting in the way. Not great for leftovers or when you have a soup pot on the stove for seconds (and thirds). I also added extra veg because that is what I always do and may add even more variety next time. I added green beans and a yellow squash but plan to add some chard and maybe some mushrooms). I used fresh tomatoes as the recipe calls for, tomato paste and water instead of canned sauce (better flavor) a big spoonful of sun-dried tomatoes from a jar I keep in the fridge and some additional herbs - bay leaf and rosemary. I didn't have wine so asked my sis to pick up a bottle on her way over. The soup was pretty bland without it and I was shocked at how much richer and more complex it was from this small addition. My suggestion, don't leave the wine out!

text:
Eternally grateful for this recipe!!  Only changes I made were to brown the sausage in a separate pan so it can be drained of fat in a colander and rinsed with hot water and drained again, thus eliminating need to skim fat off. Then I use 1-2 Tbsp. of EVOO to saute onions and garlic.  The second change was to use the half cup of red wine to deglaze the pan, then adding the broth, water, tomato sauce, carrots, sausage and proceeding with recipe. Reheats wonderfully.

12289371
Display Name:
Pixie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This one is an OMG. I was worried that my son wouldn't care for it, as he's not a big soup fan. Duh, one spoon full  did him in. My family couldn't eat it fast enough. One of the things I love about this site is the reviewer comments on how you can vary a recipe to suit your own tastes. And I am one of those people who does, often, alter a recipe for family tastes. First off, I am sure the original recipe is excellent, as I only just shifted it a bit. We hate zucchini; I swapped out peas. I used a pound of tortellini, cooked separately, instead of 8 ounces. I used chicken sausage, so I needed a teaspoon or so of olive oil so it didn't burn (no need to skim fat; the stuff is so lean). Only used 3/4 pound; that was plenty. But because it is, I cooked the onion and garlic with the sausage. I did use canned diced tomatoes; instead of draining, I used the liquid instead of the water and wine (sorry, wine gives me a migraine). I did use a bit of cornstarch to thicken it a bit. I cut the parsley to 1 tablespoon. I added several drops of hot sauce to give it a bit of zing (we're from the Buffalo NY area--we love a bit of zing). Oh, forgot, used chicken broth because I didn't have enough beef broth. I figure it doesn't much matter which you use, as others have noted. I served it with garlic bread. Just amazing. Thanks for the total inspiration!!!!!

text:
Used Chicken sausage and fresh spinach and fresh mushrooms since I didn't have a zucchini on hand.  Used vegetable broth instead of beef.  Added one small can of diced tomatoes in place of the fresh ones and omitted the tomato sauce to have a more 'broth' consistency.  Also added fresh garlic and skipped the red wine, just added a little water instead.  Soup was very tasty served with some grated pecorino cheese.  Easy and quick to make and very hearty meal!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous.  I made it for Christmas many years ago and since have been able to serve nothing in its place.  My Christmas crowd of 30 people expect this soup as the highlight of their meal.  It freezes well and so I make 4 times the recipe Christmas morning, send people home with it and freeze the leftovers for a hearty meal.  Add the tortellini only to what you expect to consume.  Make fresh tortellini for any leftovers.  I use Severoli meat tortellini as the meat adds flavor.  In the summer I freeze the vegetables straight from the garden....  Peppers and zucchini and add them to the soup straight from the freezer.  I use diced canned  tomatoes that are already seeded.  It takes a long time to peel and seed enough for 4 batches.  I have never had a better soup.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Lovely full-bodied broth, with an excellent flavor. I made exactly as written and the only differences were I used dried basil and oregano, because they were not in season in my garden, and I used fresh parsley, which grows all year around. I used hot Italian sausage and did as another cook suggested, and sauteed the onions and sausage together. I did use 6 cloves of garlic, since we like garlic. I like this soup and it reminds me a lot, in flavor, of Rachel Ray's veggie stoup, which I make repeatedly. I cooked the tortellini separately and added them in five minutes before serving, topped with a generous grating of Parmesan cheese. Wonderful soup, just like most cooks said, and I hope everyone gives it a try.

fantastic as the recipie is written...watch the salt though, use low sodium beef broth (unless you make your own stock) and don't add any additional salt at all. quick tip...use about 1 cup of water, 1 tablespoon of fresh basil packed, and eyeball the 1/2 cup of wine, I like a little more...plus , love the tip on the tortellini, add as much as you need for each serving.... well done Mary P.

THIS IS OFF THE HOOK AWESOME!!   I will start by saying i tend to love italian food and i love my italian sausage, so i figured this just made sense.  WOW was it awesome.  I made 3 minor changes that i think were for the better. text:
Excellent! I added chopped celery with the onion and carrot, threw in some fresh spinach,  had to use (2) 28 oz cans tomatoes with garlic, topped with parmesan cheese before serving. Mama Mia!!MMMwwwaaaa!Get some of those soft potato rolls to go with it. Don't skip the red wine, it gives the soup its body. You can even add a little more than called for, just be sure to taste as you add. I also used the dry cheese tortellini because I think it holds up better.

This was outstanding. I followed the recipe exactly with the exception of: using 6 cups of beef broth (1 quart size box plus one can-I didn't want leftover!) and using 1 can petite diced tomatoes (to save time and we don't like big chunks of tomato). I made this for supper last night and my husband loved it!  I substituted with what I had -- dried cheese tortellini for fresh and spinach instead of zucchini -- but it was still delicious. text:
The broth was a bit thin, but it was extremely tasty with some roasted red pepper and freshly ground black pepper. NOTE: you only need a bit more than one plastic package of beef stock, 5 cups sounds like a lot, but it really isn't very much.  getting 1 pack and a small can of beef broth is more than adequate for this recipe  I got chicken tortellini because they were out of cheese, but I don't reccomend that flavor.   I omitted the zucchini and tomato sauce, used dried basil, used a can of diced tomatoes instead of four fresh tomatoes, and omitted the wine, and used Johnsonville sweet Italian sausages.   It worked very well!

text:
AMAZING recipe.  This is our favorite on this site!!  This has been our fall football staple for 2 years now.  It's 5 stars exactly as it is...no changes necessary.    Some things we've learned:  It tastes better with fresh tomatoes verses canned.  To peel your tomatoes, drop them in boiling water for a minute.  The skins will peel right off.  We find it easier to buy ground sweet italian sausage from the meat counter, since it saves a step.  Parmesan at the end is a must! :)  ENJOY!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-10-12T22:16:09.05
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4083599
Display Name:
viciousangel
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this recipe was so good!! it has really good bones, and though i did make many modifications, it was only because i wanted it, not because it was needed. i used a roll of medium hot sausage, because it was on sale. to compensate, i added italian seasonings while browning along with a teaspoon of fennel, because i think that fennel complements the flavor of sausage. i also added cayenne pepper for kick, and allspice, because it complements the flavor of the tomatoes. i used crushed tomatoes instead of fresh because they were also on sale and for convenience. i sauteed leeks along with the onions and garlic, and i used 6 oz. of wine instead of just 4 oz. i used about an extra cup of beef broth, and omitted the water. i substituted quartered baby portabellas and spinach for the zucchini, and i started to forego the tomato sauce, but decided to add it. i am so glad i did because it gave the broth a really silky texture. i added frozen tortellini (also on sale) the last 5 minutes, then i let it sit for ten minutes before eating. finally, i topped it with parmesean cheese (on sale, of course). amazing!! this soup was so awesome, i ate almost 3 bowls with crusty bread and butter! mmmmm! fabulous recipe, and it is hearty without sending you into a food coma! the best part is the recipe made plenty and cost about 13 bucks to make! i freezed the rest and will be making this again.... kudos, mary p.!!

text:
I soaked up as much drippings as I could with a paper towel before adding the beef broth, etc. because it is much quicker than skimming the top.  We thought this was pretty good as written but just needed something more for our taste.  I ended up adding a good amount of Italian seasoning, a bit of fennel seed, and a can of Rotel tomatoes.  The green chili in the Rotel was a nice addition.  As I stated a pretty good recipe as written, we just prefer stronger flavor.

FABulous!! I followed the recipe pretty closely, but left out the onions and swapped diced chicken boiled in the beef broth for the sausage (personal preference). I added a bit more wine and was generous with the seasoning. Tomatoes aren't in season right now, so I used 2 cans of diced tomatoes. Also, after letting the soup simmer down for awhile, since I used 16oz of tortellini and it took the liquid level down some, I added a bit more broth. Leftovers, are so very yummy also! Served with warm crusty bread.

text:
This was excellent.  I made it for an italian dinner party and everyone loved it and wanted the recipe.  I used fresh tomatoes because other reviews said this was a must...don't know if it's true or not.  I used fresh sausage tortellini and think it could've been left out as it didn't add anything special other than eye appeal.  Maybe cheese tortellini would've been better, but I'd leave it out to save on cost. **Update, I make this all the time and find adding tortellini a waste of tortellini.  The soup is too good without it.  Use the tortellini as a side dish.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well...this is a very resilient recipe.  I used 2 cups of chicken broth, 1 cup of vegetable broth, and 2 cubes of beef bouillone dissolved in 2 cups hot water (I refused to go to the grocery store).  Then, I didn't have Tomato Sauce, so I used the fresh tomatoes plus added 1/2 can of petite diced partially drained.  I had some left over artichoke hearts and fresh mushrooms.  I didn't have Italian sausage, but I had Conecuh Hot Sausage...I left the casings on (too hard with this type to remove)...sauteed them in bite size pieces....drained them and threw them in the slowcooker, then sauteed the onions garlic and mushrooms and threw them in...then added all the rest that I had plus my extra stuff on low for about 7 hours.  I added BowTie pasta cooked al dente' about an hour before serving...and my daughter, hubby, and myself were raving!  Great recipe..very versitile.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/127048.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a great "let's use what's on hand" pleaser.  I used a combination of low-sodium beef broth, as well as a tablespoon of mushroom stock base.  In addition, you can add whatever vegetables you have on hand.  I added fresh green beans, chopped banana peppers, some chopped cauliflower, and a package of frozen chopped spinach, in addition to spinach-cheese tortellini.

Once the tortellini is added, you'll probably have to add additional water, broth, wine to compensate for the absorption of the liquids.  

Using fresh tomatoes reduces some of the salt complaints.  I used a mixture of tomatoes from the garden, including the yellow variety.

This soup freezes well for an easy meal when you're too tired, lazy, or busy to cook.

text:
This was the first time I made a soup - unbelievably good.  I am sure I will make this many more times in the months to come.

I didn't have a dutch oven, so I just used a large pot, and everything came out wonderfully.

-- 

Updated.  This has become "Dad's Soup".  I have made it a number of times and every time it has come out well.  I usually use a Marsala wine, which I have found to be perfect.  I have also done this with fresh and off-the-shelf tortellini (both with cheese or Italian sausage) and it has been good with either.  Additionally, I normally cook this for much longer (it is probably ready after the 1 hour, but I like this to be an all day affair, so I tend to cook for 2-4 hours).

The best thing about this is that the next day, I still have the taste in my head -- it's great.  I am going to teach my daughter's girl scout troop (Seniors) how to make this for their project where they are helping the homeless.  I am sure it will be a hit with the girls and with the homeless.

city:

text:
This was a very good soup on a cold autumn night; first time I've gotten warm today while eating it!  I scaled the recipe in half for two of us, and we ended up with a little bit leftover. I skipped the water and used all beef broth (low-sodium, which I recommend especially if you do use canned tomatoes which, like nearly any commercially processed food, also contain salt).  I didn't peel/seed fresh tomatoes (threw in one whole fresh roma because it was there!), but went with several other reviewers and did toss in a can of diced tomatoes (Muir Glen fire-roasted organic); skipped the tomato sauce altogether. Used Italian chianti wine. Cut carrots into matchsticks and added at the end with zucchini and the tortellini so they would be a bit more crunchy.  Served with a garnish of homemade pesto and a sprinkle of shredded parmesan cheese in each bowl, and freshly baked Mama D's Italian bread.  Thanks for sharing your recipe, Mary P!

5

text:
This was my first attempt at making soup. This soup was amazing! Thanks to Nikki's suggestions with using 2 carrots, 1 1/2 cans of diced tomatoes, and using one medium zucchini, prepration was pretty quick. I used Owen's Italian sausage and I did not have any red wine on hand, so I used marsala wine instead. It was DELICOUS! My husband kept going back for more. I served it with Earthgrains french bread and it made a tasty, complete meal, perfect for a cold winter day. Thanks for the recipe, my husband is already requesting it again soon!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to change this recipe to suit what I had on hand.  So here's how it looked.
I fried up the sausage (I used mild.)  Removed it and added the onions and garlic (I used 4 cloves).  I didn't find I had any fat with the sausage so I added some of my own.  I used 5 cups of water with 6 packets of oxo.  Skipped adding extra liquid in place of the wine and also did not add that extra half cup of water.  For the tomatoes I used a 28 ounce can of diced tomatoes that I didn't drain.  I also added a large can of tomato sauce, probably more like 12 to 16 ounces.  I didn't have fresh basil so I used dried.  I skipped the zucchini.  I also skipped the fresh parsley.
I added a little italian seasoning and some hot pepper flakes to make up for the missing heat I would have had by using a hot sausage.
The soup tastes terrific.  Maybe one day I'll get to make it with all of the ingredients listed.  I'm sure it would be wonderful!

text:
I needed a nice soup to go with an Italian themed dinner for guests. This soup is unbeleivable, I have gotten nothing but raves on it. The first time I made it I used fresh basil, the second time I used dry. They were both great, but the one using dry tasted a bit more like "pizza" than the fresh. Be sure to let the sausage brown nicely, it adds a lot of great flavor. This is going in my archives for good!

text:
This soup was terrific!  My husband thought it was the best soup he has ever tasted.  The only thing I did differently was cook the soup the night before leaving the tortellini out and heated it up in the crock pot the next day.  I cooked the tortellini seperatly and added it to the soup before serving.  Worked perfectly.  I didn't really care for the soup the following day after the tortellini had been added mainly because they had swollen to about twice their size.  It was the look of it rather than the taste.

Rainy autumn day here today & we enjoyed this for dinner tonight. I basically followed the recipe but used spicy Italian sausage rather than sweet, dried basil rather than fresh, and canned tomatoes, carrots & zucchini. Also added lots of extra garlic because we love it. Garnished with freshly grated Parmesan, along with a few Parmesan shavings. I did simmer all day in slow cooker (after browning sausage), except for adding tortellini last few minutes. Wonderful flavorful soup----my husband especially enjoyed.....early in the meal said it's a 'keeper'. :)

This happened to be the first time I've made this soup or any soup for that matter, and it absolutely got MANY rave reviews. It was made for a church function so I change the serving portions to 25, I was on the verge of blushing from so many compliments. I did take the advise of others and used half hot and half sweet sausage, which I think really gives this soup the hearty flavor. And yes the tortellini does soak up much of the stock and it was referred to as stew by many. I've had to give the recipe out to many and my husband has even requested it again.

Bellisimo!!!(sp?) For my vegetarian comrades- here is what I did. I used the Morningstar sausage patties, cooked them up and then chopped in food processor. I used a 28 oz can of whole tomatoes,also chopped them in the food processor. Then added a 16 oz can of tomato soup (I had no tomato sauce).The only other changes was a tad more wine and I know I added more spice than what the recipe called for. Also added some Essence. Served with warm crusty french bread!!! Will make again and again! Thank you!

text:
I've made this many times after I was stationed in NJ and learned some IT cooking techniques.  This is a good recipe to start with.  Add a few minced cloves of garlic with the onion.  And don't skimp on the veggies.  Zuccini is great, but any long squash will do, in addition to wilted spring spinach added in.   I use chicken broth for a lighter taste to bring out the flavors and use Hot Italian Sausage to bring a bit of POW to the mix. 
Cheers

text:
I did make several changes.  I had no fresh tomatoes so I used 2-14.5 oz cans diced tomatoes.  I used 1 t. dry basil, 1 t. dry oregano, 2 t. dry parsley.  I used a 4 oz. package of fresh spinach instead of the zucchini, adding it just a couple of minutes before serving.  Did not use any wine.  And I used 24 oz of tortellini.  Lots of changes, I know, but we loved it!  I've even made it once with chicken broth instead of beef and it's just as good!

I used a cheese grater for the onion, garlic and zucchini. I didn't have red wine, so I substituted it for red wine vinegar. 

people said it was salty so I made sure to use low sodium broth. I added a tsp of brown sugar for the acidity in the tomatoes, tsp of red pepper flakes to keep it flavorful, and a tablespoon of cream because I like creamy soups. 

very flavorful! my mother said it tasted like a restaurant and everyone else in my family finished their plates.

text:
Wow wow wow!  What excellent soup!  
I followed the recipe closely...but I used dried herbs and canned tomatoes.  If I had farm-to-table tomatoes I would use those but in the winter when tomatoes taste like nothing I use canned.  I would buy fresh basil for this but they were out at the store.  Definitely use more broth then it calls for, at least 6 cups. I would have liked more brother overall.  There wasn't enough broth even keeping the noodles out.  And like others have stated, it's on the salty side.  Next time I will increase the water to 2 cups so I have more broth and less salt taste.  My husband who hates Italian sausage and zucchini loved it!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made some slight changes- skipped adding water, and did 4 cups of beef broth instead of 5, since it comes in a 1 quart container.  With less liquid I only simmered everything for about 35-40 minutes.  I only had sweet sausage so I made it "hot" by adding paprika and red pepper flakes.  The frozen tortellini I bought said boil for 3-4 minutes, so I did that instead of the recommended 10.  One package of tortellini (slightly over a pound) seemed like a better amount instead of only 8oz worth.

With the tweaks, it was absolutely delicious.  I was apprehensive about a tomato-based soup, since I hate tomato soup, but it came out great.  Hearty without being too rich like chowder is.

This was a hit tonight for dinner! I made a few changes, not because it wasn't fine the way it was but because I didn't have some of the specific ingredients on hand. I added mushrooms because we love them and other than having to buy sausage and zucchini at the store, I had everything else in my kitchen.  I did wait to add the zucchini until I put in the pasta because my husband is not a fan of mushy veggies. He and both kids had 2 helpings!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty recipe! I used hot turkey sausage (1/2lb) mixed with 1/2 lb 85/15 ground beef. I seasoned the meat with fennel, oregano, garlic powder, and red pepper flakes. I let  the meat  set overnight. I blanched the tomatoes, so they were easy to peel. I used fresh herbs versus dry in the soup. I also added thyme and bay leaf. As far as vegetables, I added one red bell pepper for color.  I used 6 cups of broth and a 1/2 cup water so the pasta wouldn’t absorb all the broth. It was a hit at my luncheon and some guest even ask for a second serving.

text:
Well liked.  Just a few alteration/additions:
cook tortillini separate,
just use 2 cans undrained tomatoes instead of 4 tomatoes and 1/2 c water,
add 1 c spinach and 1 can garbanzo beans last 10 min of cooking,
add frozen corn halfway through first 30 min simmer,
garnish with fresh parm ,
serve with grilled french bread (butter each side, cook, sprinkle with parm and cover skillet to melt it)

country:
None
text:
This is a delicious  soup recipe! I did a few things differently than what the recipe calls for though.   I used a good quality canned plum tomatoes instead of  fresh tomatoes.  Also for a lighter version I used Italian chicken sausage.  I love mushrooms so I  added 1/2 dozen sliced shiitake mushrooms  to the soup.  I cooked the tortellini's in the soup however  I took the advice of a previous rating that said they will absorb too much of the broth if you leave them in the soup.  So once they were finished cooking I took them out  of the soup  to add later at meal time.

Display Name:
Raeleen Sewell

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/45929.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Though I changed this recipe up based on what I had, it was a great starting point.  Used about 8 cups chicken broth instead of beef and no water; used ground Italian sausage; did not use tomato sauce or wine; used 1 can diced tomatoes and 1 whole yellow squash; used all dried spices including Italian blend; used at least 6 cloves of garlic; added about 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes to the veggies while sauteing (note that I saute the carrots and squash with the onions and garlic along with the sausage and some extra evoo); a couple of dashes of liquid aminos to the broth (a staple in my kitchen); added a couple of handfuls of fresh arugula, the entire container of fresh tortellini, and s&p to taste.  It was completely consumed by all (including the picky 8-year old!)  Definitely a keeper and many thanks for the inspiration!

text:
GREAT soup! My dad well doesn't care for souls loved it as well as two guy friends I shared it with. I made a couple mild substitutions based off of what I read.Used 2 green zucchini and 1 yellow zucchini. Used 16 ounces of frozen tortellini. Put in extra basil and used rosemary in soup along with other herbs.Use an extra cup/cup and a half of beef broth (6.5 cups total.) It helped so there was still liquid after the tortellini absorbs a lot of the broth. Also use a half pound of mild sausage and half pound of hot sausage.For tomatoes, I put in 2 cans of drained cubed petite tomatoes. Would possibly add some spinach for a little extra something.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic right after you make it, but it is even better as leftovers!  I used frozen tortellini, canned (drained) tomatoes, and sherry wine (instead of red) because that's what I had and it turned out excellent.

I know some people recommended making the tortellini separate as you eat the soup, but I do not recommend this at all!  The tortellini does soak up a lot of the broth, but it is SOOO yummy that way!  I think that's why it tastes better the next day, because all the flavor has soaked into the tortellini!  So leave it in!
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GREAT recipe! So yummy! I followed the cooking instructions directly but I did make some changes to the ingredients (based on what I had and what I had read in other reviews) But I think it turned out really well! Sub. 1.5 lbs. mild Italian sausage), 6 cups of beef broth, one cup frozen chopped spinach to replace zucchini, no water, a bigger package of frozen cheese tortellini, 1.5 cans of diced tomatoes (DONT drain!) instead of fresh tomatoes. I read that the soup can become more of a stew because the tortellini soaks up the juice so I tried to add a bit more liquid to see if I could truly make it a “soup”. It still turned out to be more of a thick stew instead of a soup but we didn’t care; it smelled delicious while we were cooking it and it tasted AMAZING! Tasted just as good for leftovers the next day :)

text:
We enjoyed this soup! I will make it again. I made this soup following the recipe. This is what I did to make it my own. I added more beef broth to equal 7 cups. I added beef marrow bones for extra flavor. I used canned tomatoes because that's all I had. I used dried cheese tortellini that I cooked separately according to the package directions. The result was delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great soup and very different from any I have ever made before.  I was a little hesitant to try it only because I usually do not care for tomato based soups, but this one is wonderful!  My store was out of zucchin so I added a handful of fresh spinach with the tortellini instead and the only other change was I used dried basil because again, did not have fresh.  Next time I will make sure I have both, but this soup is super yummy and there will definitely be a next time.  It does make a lot for 2 people and when I did was add the pasta into it so it would be flavored, but then when I was putting it away I took the tortellini out of the soup and stored them separately and then always added some back into each bowl before re-heating in the microwave.  We had a nice dinner and quite a few lunches.  Re-warms in the microwave beautifully.  Just a great, great soup and I will be making this often!  Thanks!

I have since made it several times with the zucchini and fresh basil and have also cut the recipe in 1/2 and its a really favorite of ours!  Thanks again!

Flavorful, delicious soup. Made per recipe except for the following changes:
-Excluded wine
-Used ground sausage
-1/4 tsp garlic powder
-1/2 tsp dried basil
-3 tsp dried parsley
-diced, canned tomatoes (1 to 1.5 cans, 14oz)
-16 ounces tortellini pasta (doubled it)
*Cooked in large pot on stove top. Boiled tortellini in soup, then served. Tasted great without simmering for 30 mins.

text:
This was nice although to be honest, I liked it much better the next day! I used fresh herbs and a can of Rotel which gave it a kick. First day when we had it for dinner with fresh baked biscuits, I thought, meh, it was ok. BUT, each day it got better and better! Gave some to my neighbor, she added sour cream and LOVED it! So YES, I would make it again. Tip though, definitely don't add too many tortellini- you can always add more later and when you make it for the first time, just undercook the pasta and shut stove off and let it finish. Hope this helps?
