The recipe looks good as is, however I wanted a rich stock/ broth base. To create that,  I browned marrow bones and added onion, celery and carrots and T. Tomato paste. . Added box stock. Cooked it for a couple hours and then strained into pot before I began.  I also added carrot and celery and bell pepper to the soup. Again, not necessary but added nutritional value.

text:
Amazing! It turned out even better than I thought! 

This was my first time making it, so I followed the recipe exactly (except I used hot Italian sausage since that's all they had.. and we like spicy) so I could give an accurate review. It was delicious, but took far longer than indicated. I am going to cheat next time and use canned diced tomatoes and see if there's a significant difference.

I followed the advice of many other reviewers. I made the tortellini separately as needed. It tasted great, so unless you're going to eat it all in one meal I would recommend doing the same. The pasta will absorb the liquid while stored in the fridge otherwise.

text:
I am on the second batch in three days.  Teenage boys and husband loved it!  We don't eat zucchini so I substituted fresh baby spinach.  Perfect.  I used the only red wine I had around, a Chilean "red wine".  I don't think it matters which wine you use.  Also, I used fresh oregano and fresh thyme and no parsley. I highly recommend you add diced celery to the onion and garlic sauce.   I'm convinced you can tweak this recipe however you like.  Enjoy!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time last night, and everyone LOVED it. I made the following changes:  doubled the garlic; used half of a small yellow onion; one leek; used one teaspoon of dried oregano; one teaspoon of red pepper flakes for a kick; one dried bay leaf; mild Italian sausage; tortellini with sweet Italian sausage; and two 14.5 oz cans of fire roasted tomatoes (strained), in lieu of the four whole fresh tomatoes. I added the fresh basil during the last ten minutes of cooking (when I added the tortellini). Finally, I just added a pinch of kosher salt during the last 20 minutes. It was fabulous!

region:

country:
None
text:
This turned out fantastic!  Made it exactly like the recipe calls for, with one exception.  I cooked the tortellini separate because I only wanted to cook as much as we would eat, as the soup is very plentiful and I knew we would have leftovers.  I used a relatively inexpensive bottle of 'Red Table Wine' which actually wasn't terrible on its own.  you could make this without wine, however, I think it really rounded out the flavor profile of the broth.   I also used low sodium broth and didn't add any salt to the soup.  It was plenty flavorful without any additional salt.   Even my picky 13 year old son gobbled this up, and he doesn't even like zucchini.   I will be making this again.  Thanks!

2662857
Display Name:
ChefJen
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3971319.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was sooooo yummy!  I made it for my ladie's Bunco group.  I had planned on doubling the recipe but I actually doubled all the ingredients and did 2.5x for the beef broth/tomato sauce/wine.  I used a low sodium beef broth and eliminated the water.  I used Roma tomatoes and put an "x" on top of them, threw them in a pot of hot water for about a minute, then easily peeled them and scooped out the seeds.  I used some fresh cheese tortellini that I got from Costco.  I let the soup cook about 5 hours before adding the zucchini and parsley.  I added the pasta about 20 min before serving.  I topped the soup with some fresh shaved parmesan and served with some garlic bread.  It was a huge hit!!  I think the key is- using a good quality beef broth or stock and a good quality tortellini + fresh tomatoes- it makes a huge difference.
Review:

5

jean66

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love this soup.  I've made it so many times since it is so satisfying.
Some changes and suggestions:
1.  Use plum tomatoes so you don't have to peal or seed.
2.  I usually leave the zucchini out and double the carrots
3.  To make this low fat and reduce the oil to skim (to nothing!), I use hot Italian turkey sausage.  Reduces the calories and taste is identical
4.  Add more broth (I usually go with 6 cups)
5.  Add the tortellini only to what you are serving/reheating.  They will bloat if they are stored in the soup.

text:
I don't like to rate recipes I've changed, but this recipe is "tweakable".  I didn't have fresh tomatoes, so I used a can of diced tomatoes (then omitted the sauce).  I used all beef broth (no wine on hand) and used 6 cups.  Instead of zucchini (because I knew my kids wouldn't eat it), I added a cup of chopped spinach.  I put in 16 ozs dried tortellini which then required an additional cup or so of broth or water.  Really good soup!

country:
None
text:
I have made this many times.  At first, I made it as written, which is 5 stars.  Now, I have realized that it really can be a simple, fast weeknight meal.  1) Use a 25-32 ounce jar of your favorite pasta sauce instead of the tomatoes.  2) No need for the two 30-minute simmering.  Just simmer uncovered until the carrots are tender, then add the tortellini.  I often leave out the zucchini if I don't have it.

text:
This was a definitely a hit with my wife and I.  Some notes to consider:
Use a high quality tortellini.  I used store brand 1x and it did not turn out nearly as good.
Leftovers get mushy (tortellini & zucchini mainly) pretty quickly.  Best eaten fresh, ok next day.
Red wine vinegar works if you don't have red wine available.

None
text:
This was amazing! I modified based on time and ingredients, and cooked in a crock pot. I used leftover frozen onions and green beans and diced jalapeños, can mushrooms, fresh sliced carrots, some minced garlic, two jugs beef broth, can tomato sauce, large can crushed tomatoes, tablespoon each dried basil and oregano. Added lots of salt and pepper. I seared mild Italian sausage links and tossed in crock pot. Took 5 minutes the night before. Cooked on low while at work next day. Took out sausages, sliced up and back in crock pot with frozen cheese tortellini. Cooked another hour or so. Served with mozzarella cheese! This was fabulous!!

text:
This was actually good, but I need to perfect it more next time. I used more beef broth in lieu of the pasta soaking up too much, added a whole can of water, little more than 1/2 cup red wine, one can of tomato sauce, one 28 oz roasted tomatoes, one can vegetable broth, 2 cans of low salt corn, celery, green pepper, and a lot of onion. I seasoned with garlic powder, italian seasoning, red pepper flakes, and oregano. I added sausage and cheese stuffed tortellini toward the end, and added 4 cheese fat free Italian cheese on top. Turned out a little too "tomatoey" for my taste. Garlic toast was great as a side. Next time I will add more meat and vegetables and not so much tomatoes.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is probably a great recipe. I do make this soup without a recipe though. I brown sausage meat and food process it- remove it to a bowl, saute onion and garlic and add wine and cook a little. I use Lipton onion soup mix and heat it but add extra water. If I use a large amount of sausage I sometimes use extra onion soup mix. I simmer the cooked ground  sausage onion and garlic. Later add chopped can tomatoes with juice and cook it some more. I later add plenty of spinach and cook to ready. If I do not have fresh shinach I use chopped frozen, defrosted spinach drained.   I have also made rice to add to individual bowls and top with thin slices of mozzarella cheese. I am adding in some corn this time also. I did make up my recipe myself and am glad to find one similar to mine. If I make a large pot and want to freeze some I do it before the spinach, rice and cheese.

None
text:
I have made this soup for large amounts of people.  Served with a side salad and fresh Italian bread it becomes a awesome meal on a cold winters day. 
I usually follow the recipe, and always use fresh organic ingredients.  I also always buy my sausage fresh from the butcher.   
Depending on who I am feeding it to I will vary it from sweet or mild sausage.  Never hot otherwise it just over powers the other ingredients.  
Thank you so much!

userID:
11679230
Display Name:
Jeanne
isPro:

29
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is our family's favorite soup for a crowd (or the freezer!) with a few minor changes:  I increase amounts of Italian sausage to 1.5 lbs, double the amount of fresh garlic to 4 cloves, substitute a large can of quality crushed tomatoes, add 4 - 6 handfuls of fresh washed baby spinach (stemmed), a chopped bell pepper, 1/2 cup fresh chopped basil and fresh chopped Italian flat leaf parsley.  This soup is best if made early in the morning, simmered for 1 hour and rested all day to blend flavours.  Reheat and add tortellini last 20 minutes. Top each serving with additional fresh herbs and fresh grated or sliced parmesan.  Crusty  sourdough is our usual bread, but I like another reviewer's suggestion to try the foccacia bread recipe from this site and will try it with this soup tomorrow!

text:
Yummy!!  I love making soups because you can always play around and alter the ingredients to your taste or to what you have on hand.  I followed this recipe, except I used a can of whole San Marzano tomatoes (then I crushed them), omitted the tomato sauce, used 32 oz of beef broth and 1 cup of wine, and I used Italian dried herbs instead of fresh basil and oregano.  I used hot chicken sausage to save on some calories.  Overall a very hearty soup that even my husband liked!

This soup as made the list of one of my FAVORITE soups!! it's absolutely delicious, hearty, filling, easy, and quick to make. I did add a few extra veggies.,and served it with a rustic garlic crusted Italian  bread. I used Marsala cooking wine because that's what I had available. I also added 1 chopped celery stalk, 1/2 of green Bell pepper cut into big chuncks, 1 package of fresh baby spinach, can of diced Italian tomatoes and 1 small fresh tomato, I also used tomato paste instead of the sauce for a more thicker broth. Deliciousyo!!

I made this soup as is the first time and it was excellent! I used what I had on hand this time. Ground turkey in place of the sausage, one whole onion, 4 minced cloves of garlic, 6 cups of beef broth (no water, and I didn't have any wine) I used three small carrots, 3 dried bay leaves, italian seasoning, ground pepper, a bit of leftover tomato sauce, a large can of diced tomatoes, and a can of low sodium tomato soup. text:
quadrupled the recipe and served it at a church social.  Many compliments! The pot was empty.  I will be making this again.  Be careful with the pasta though, as it acts like a sponge and absorbs all the broth.  I used mini bow-tie (mini farfalle) pasta instead of tortellinii to save $. Next time, I will bring the cooked pasta lightly tossed with olive oil and add it to the soup right before serving.  Wondrful soup!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1695679.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a little bit more than a pound of sausage, and if I did it again, I might use even more. So if you have more than a pound on hand, don't be afraid to use it all. Also, I personally prefer chopped baby carrots to sliced carrots in soup (more meaty carrot pieces). Other than that, this recipe is perfect.

A day or two after cooking this, you'll notice a lot of built up oil and fat from the sausage. This can be easily skimmed off because it builds at the top. Skimming the fat while the pot is cooking can be very difficult, but it is very easy later and really helps keep the soup smooth. The soup has plenty of flavor without it, so don't worry.

Really delicious!  My husband enjoyed it too!  I substituted a can of diced tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes (that's what I had in my pantry).  I didn't have fresh parsley or basil, so I omitted the parsley and used dried basil instead. It still turned out really good!  After reading a few reviews, I used more beef broth than what was called for, as I didn't want the tortellini to soak up all of the broth, especially if you have leftovers. The wine gives the soup an extra depth of flavor and richness! Top it off with fresh grated parmesan cheese before serving!!
Review:

5

text:
Wow, this was really fantastic!  I only used  32 oz of Kitchen Basics brand Beef Stock.  I should have added another 2 cups because my soup seemed kind of chunky.  It needed more broth. I used fresh tomatoes, as the recipe called for.  I started it really early (around 2:30 pm).  Just let it simmer until dinner time.  The broth was to die for.  Reminded me of the sauce in Beef Bourginion. My advice, use a really good brand of beed broth/stock and do not leave the wine out.  It will not be the same.  It's such a dark and rich broth.  I will most definitely make this again.  You could also make this with kale instead of zucchini.  I might even like that better.  I removed the casing from the sausage and then cut it in little bite sized pieces.

text:
Excellent and quick and easy to make. I've made this several times. I add my onions to the sausage when the sausage is about 1/2 way cooked. I use a can of fire roasted tomatoes instead of fresh, and used low sodium beef broth (4 cups cause that's what I had) I used fresh oregano and skipped the basil since I didn't have any. And add water as needed, about 1 1/2 cups. I also added a handful of spinach. This is a versatile recipe, but I really think you need the beef not the chicken broth/ stock. Thanks for this awesome meal!

text:
Very good.  I made some subs because of that I had on hand.  I think it would be better if you stuck to the main recipe which is why I gave it five start.  It really is excellent.

I didn't have fresh basil (hard to find in January, so I used dried basil and parsley.  Fresh herbs are ALWAYS better if you can get them!

I added and extra cup of broth because of some of the other reviews which I think was a good choice.

I didn't have zucchini so I just had the carrots and fresh tomato.  I would NOT used canned tomato in this recipe personally. But this was still good because there was a lot more broth and the flavor of the red wine and broth is DIVINE!

I used pesto tortellini. My husband LOVED that, but I think I would have liked cheese better. Though with the fresh basil pesto might go pretty well~

Overall, fantastic recipe.  Definitely a keeper!

Display Name:
DEVSOL
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this yesterday and it turned out super. I un-cased the sausage and put it into a mixing bowl. I used a stiff spatula to knead it for a couple of minutes. Somehow this makes is snappy. I made two 1/2 lb. 6 inch patties and seared them in an untreated skillet. Went back to the soup and had to add a little olive oil to sauté the onions and garlic. When I got to the point that I wanted to add the sausage the patties had cooled a little. I stacked them one on top of the other and cut them into bite sized pieces. I was amazed that they stayed together in spite of being rare inside. I added them to the soup and followed the directions. When the soup was done the bite sized pieces cooked up nicely in the simmering broth. I though it added a nice visual effect to the soup and I also like the snap when you bite into the pieces. Thanks Mary P for a great recipe and to the folks from Cook's Illustrated for bringing this method of treating pork sausage to my attention. Bon Appetite!
Review:

5

text:
Have to admit that I didn't follow it to a T (or is it tee?)...anyway, so I used what I had on hand.  One cup of chx broth in the fridge so I threw that in...and I had no beef broth so I used a cube of bouillon and a little pod of stock which I put into boiling water to make the beef broth needed.  I didn't have zucchini but wound up throwing in celery and red pepper.  I didn't have tortellini either but used anelli pasta instead. On top of that, I had no fresh herbs so I used dried.  Regardless, since I'd never made it before, I didn't know the difference and this tasted fantastic.  I put fresh grated parmigiano-reggiano on top with fresh parsley (I did have that)...and both my husband and I loved it.  I will gladly make again and again.

dateLastModified:
2013-11-25T17:02:38.337
helpfulCount:

userID:
849226
Display Name:
Shannon
isPro:
False
followersCount:
18
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
303
favoritesCount:
1148
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2787858.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A perfect hearty soup for a cold fall/winter night! Beyond the usual prep time, this is fairly easy to throw together.  It's also simple enough to sub ingredients or use up what you have on hand. I used 6-7 cups of water and added a combo of Better Than Bouillion beef and chicken bases. Used Johnsonville 1/2 pork 1/2 chicken sausage, shaped into tiny meatballs, which is FANTASTIC in flavor and also because there isn't any grease to drain or skim. Doubled up on basil since oregano isn't a family favorite, and also seasoned the broth with onion and garlic powders as well as a good dose of black pepper. Used a good quality garnacha wine and used slightly more than 1/2 cup. Used 1 can of fire roasted tomatoes as well as a roughly-chopped roma tomato, and even added in a handful of grape tomatoes that I wanted to use up. No zucchini on hand, so I tossed in some fresh spinach, a 20oz package of a 3-cheese tortellini, and simmered to perfection.  Leftovers tonight were also great...just added some hot water to reheat.  I like to add crushed roasted garlic bagel crisps to my bowl, but garlic bread is a superb side,  as well as a great way to sop up the deliciousness!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-11-23T20:10:03.343

text:
This was really tasted, but I made several changes.  I omitted the water, increased the wine to 1 1/2 cups, and increased the beef broth to 6 cups.  I also added 2 cups of spinach the last 10 mins of cooking.  In addition to all the hebs listed in the recipe I used onion powder, garlic powder, Worcester sauce, and some creole seasoning while the soup was simmering, it was just a little too bland for me.  As another reviewer suggested, I made a cornstarch slurry to thicken up the broth a bit and boiled the tortellini separately and added them before serving.  Overall this was a great recipe that I will make again.

Absolutely WONDERFUL!!! My home smelled like heaven!  I did alter the recipe just a tad to use what I had on hand.  Instead of the fresh tomatoes, I used two large cans of diced tomatoes (strained to remove excess liquid) & substituted  frozen green beans for the zucchini. I tossed in the frozen green beans in step "2" of the recipe, which worked well because they were still firm at the end of the cooking time.  My Husband loved it and said "we'll be making this again!"  Thanks so much to Mary P. for sharing such a wonderful, beautiful dish! Candee

text:
Yum! Used sweet Italian style chicken sausage, so virtually no fat. Sautéed the onions and garlic in olive oil. Used pesto-stuffed tortellini for an awesome flavor. Hearty winter time soup, although I forgot to cover during the last half hour of simmering and lost much of the liquid. Next time I'll either add more broth or remember to cover it!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/266760.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this tonight and it was fantastic.  Next time I'll skip the zucchini - family wasn't too thrilled about that part!
I used 2 cans petite diced tomatoes (drained) instead of cutting them myself.  I also added a bit more red wine- almost a full cup.  I removed the casings from the sausage by making a vertical slit down the middle of the sausage and then just stripped the casing from the sausage.  I only had 4 cups beef broth so I used a cup of chicken broth in addition to the 4 cups beef broth.  I didn't have parsley on hand so that step got skipped.  It was full of flavor and enough to freeze for a 2nd meal later on with some fresh baked french bread from the bakery.

text:
Oh my gosh, we love this soup! I used the 1 pound role of Jimmy Dean sausage.  I omitted the zucchini and added a cup of chopped (FRESH not frozen) spinach.  The spinach gave it good color and even my children (who dislike spinach,) loved this soup!  I also did what others suggested and added a can of diced tomatos (with the juice)instead of the whole, fresh ones.  We didnt have tortellini in, so I added shell noodles. Any pasta noodles will do fine with this soup. This is definitely a keeper recipe.  So easy to make!

text:
OH MY LORDY MERCY!!!! This was so fricken good!!!!  My 7 year old son even kept coming back for more.  I did use HOT Italian sausage cus our family likes it a little on the spicy side.  I also put a couple of huge handfuls of fresh spinach in there when I added the frozen cheese tortellini.  If you don’t like spicy spicy, don’t use HOT Italian sausage because it is spicy.  Adding spinach adds a nice touch and sneaks even more good for you veggies into the meal.  I will tell you that my Italian hubby absolutely loved this meal!!!  He normally complains that soup does not fill him up but this one he got full and really enjoyed!  Thanks Mary P for the amazing recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE: MY HUBS HAS A TERRIBLE HEAD COLD. WHEN ASKED WHAT HE WANTED FOR DINNER, GE SAID HE HAD A TASTE FOR TORTELLINI OF ALL THINGS LOL! I IMMEDIATELY THOUGHT OF THIS SOUP. THIS TIME, I FOLLOWED THE RECIPE VERY CLOSELY ( I EVEN USED FRESH TOMATOES - WHICH I DON'T THINK MADE THAT MUCH DIFFERENCE, IMHO) BUT INSTEAD OF SWEET SAUSAGE , I USED THE HOT KIND . OUR SOUP WAS FANTASTIC (EVEN BETTER THAN LAST TIME. NOTE: BE SURE TO COOK YOUR PASTA SEPARATELY THO... IT WILL SOAK UP ALMOST ALL THE BROTH OTHERWISE. :) Yum! VERY good!!! This is delicious, complex and well-seasoned. It requires little modification, but as with any new recipe I try, I couldn't resist making a few minor changes. :) I pretty much followed Mary's directions to the letter except for subbing 1 1/2 (14.5 oz.) cans of organic petite diced tomatoes for fresh ones (I didn't have time to boil/peel/seed/dice/etc.), Italian seasoning for oregano (I couldn't find the bottle of oregano I just bought - argh!) and dried tri-colored cheese tortellini for the refrigerated variety. Other than these three changes, I followed Mary's directions exactly. I only needed two medium-sized carrots and one medium zucchini as Nikki suggested (right on!). Garnished bowlfuls with shredded Parm and some fresh chopped basil (a definite must) and served with warm ciabatta rolls and the rest of the cabernet sauvignon I used in the soup. :-) Thanks for sharing, Mary!

text:
I made this last night - very good.  And even better second day!  I did make a few adjustments just based on personal preferences.  To supplement the vegetables I added celery and also spinach (frozen, at the very end).  I also added a can of great northern white beans as I like white beans and sausage together.  I also used canned diced tomatoes instead of the fresh.  All in all a hearty and tasty soup - and very easy to make!

text:
My husband and I loved this, so when my mom needed a main dish for a church dinner for 18 adults, I made her a batch.  She loved it, and so did the church group.  It was "just different enough" to still be a crowd-pleaser.

The only changes I made were for convenience.  I used a can of peeled/diced tomatoes, substituted jar spaghetti sauce for a can since I had it on hand, and used bulk Italian sausage instead of removing the casings.  Still tasted great!

text:
I made quite a few minor changes to this recipe. I had some precooked ground sausage already in my freezer, so I just used that and sauteed my veggies in extra virgin olive oil. I added in 1/2 tsp. dried basil in step 2 and did not add in the fresh basil until the very end, right before I served the soup. I also substituted a 15 oz can of crushed tomatoes for the fresh tomatoes. I omitted the can of tomato sauce. Everyone in the family absolutely loved it!

I'll try it again right in a while ... after we've recovered from the sodium overdose.

This is great.  I used sweet sausage and added a pinch of cayenne pepper to the pot.  I have made it with plain diced petite tomatoes and with 1.5 cans of stewed tomatoes. text:
Decent recipe with some good flavors, although it took FOREVER to make!

I would recommend ditching the dutch-oven technique and pan frying the sausage--this will substantially cut your time. Also, try to find a lean sausage because, even though I was able to drain/skim the fat a little, I was still left with a slightly unappetizing, greasy spoon.

text:
This is the most amazing and versatile soup. During the winter I make it almost weekly. In fact, my husband invited my in-laws over last minute and rather than making a whole new meal, we had the soup (since it was already made) and they loved it. A few adaptions I have made are this: I use Isernio's Italian Chicken Sausage and I actually like it better. I also changed the cheese tortellini for dried pesto tortellini (Trader Joes) and I increased the liquid to about 7.5 cups of beef broth. With these adaptions it is about 150 calories a serving.

text:
Wow!!!  This soup was WONDERFUL!!!  We will definately make this again, and again!  I made a few changes based on the previous reviews.  2 big containers of chicken broth and water (didn't feel like opening a bottle of wine for just a little bit) I added a can of cannellini beans and blended them in when I added the broth.  Then I added 2 cans of petite diced tomatoes.  I also added a couple of handfuls of spinach when I put the tortellini in.  I don't like my veggies mushy in soup, so I cooked the initial 30 minutes and added the spinach, zucchini and tortellini together at the end.

city:

country:

text:
This recipe is very good.  I made a couple of changes, since I had little time for cooking it midweek.  First, I used the dry in-the-bag type of tortellini noodles, and cooked them in the soup COVERED for about 11/12 minutes at the very end.  This cooked them just right and saved some money.  I really didn't like the hassle of peeling and chopping tomatoes, since I think they would've tasted just as good from a can.  Next time I'll do this and hopefully save even more time.  The soup itself tasted wonderful--my children even ate all of the veggies in it because the stock was so flavorful.  Excellent fall/winter soup!

We made a couple of changes:  14.5 ounces of diced tomatoes instead of 4 fresh tomatoes, increased the tomato sauce to 14.5 ounces, and increased to 12 ounces of tortellini.  It made enough for two full dinners for our family of four.

text:
Very tasty but came out a tad salty (will look for low- or no-salt bullion next time; I used packets this time that didn't say anything re salt content). Wasn't crazy about the tortellini; it was kinda chewy even though it was bought fresh from the refrig. section at the store. I'll try regular pasta (e.g., elbows) next time. Used turkey sausage and that worked out great. Zucchini kinda got squishy - more a texture than a flavor - and that was fine. Could use more carrots! Do try this recipe and plan on tweaking! Great on a cold day!

It was fantastic - almost my favorite soup recipe (second only to Stephanie G's Creamy Chicken and Wild Rice recipe).
